questions.text: A 40-year-old adult presents to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath, chest pain, and absent breath sounds on one side of the chest. Chest radiograph for which is given below. Where would you perform the management procedure for chest decompression?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 5th Intercostal Space, Midaxillary Line:

  • The given case is of tension pneumothorax, in case of an adult, needle puncture at 5th intercostal space at mid axillary line.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 2nd Intercostal Space, Midclavicular Line: It is in case of children.

Option B -  2nd Intercostal Space, Midaxillary Line: Like option A, the 2nd intercostal space carries the risk of injuring the internal mammary vessels. Additionally, the midaxillary line might not provide the optimal angle for decompression in severe cases of tension pneumothorax. The 5th intercostal space, midaxillary line, offers a safer and more effective alternative.

Option D - 5th Intercostal Space, Midclavicular Line: While the 5th intercostal space is the correct level, the midclavicular line is not the preferred location for chest decompression in adults.

questions.text:
Which of the following are clinical features of Addison's disease?


	Postural Hypotension
	Hyperglycemia
	Hyperpigmentation
	Hypokalemia
	Hypercalcemia
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Clinical features of Addison's disease typically include:

1.Postural Hypotension: This is a common symptom in Addison's disease. The adrenal glands don't produce enough hormones, including aldosterone, which can lead to low blood pressure, especially when changing positions.

3.Hyperpigmentation: People with Addison's disease often experience increased skin pigmentation, especially in sun-exposed areas. This is due to elevated levels of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which can stimulate melanin production.

5.Hypercalcemia: Hypercalcemia, or high levels of calcium in the blood is  associated with Addison's disease. 

Incorrect Options:

2.Hyperglycemia: While people with Addison's disease may have lower cortisol levels, which can affect blood sugar regulation, hyperglycemia is not a primary or consistent feature of Addison's disease. Instead, hypoglycemia (low blood sugar) can occur in some cases.

3.Hypokalemia: Hypokalemia, or low levels of potassium in the blood, is not common feature of Addison's disease, instead hyperkalemia is seen in this condition.

questions.text: What is the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Cholesterolosis:

  • Cholesterolosis, it refers to a condition where the gallbladder wall is infiltrated by cholesterol-laden macrophages, giving the mucosa a stippled appearance, which might resemble polyps on imaging. It's a benign condition often found incidentally during imaging studies or surgeries.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Cholesterol Polyposis: Cholesterol polyps refer to small outgrowths of the gallbladder wall composed of cholesterol deposits. These are benign lesions and are not true polyps but rather cholesterol deposits.

Option B- Adenomyomatosis: Adenomyomatosis is a benign condition characterized by hyperplasia (abnormal increase in cells) of the mucosal epithelium of the gallbladder, leading to excessive outpouching of the mucosal layer into the muscle layer. It often appears as multiple small cystic spaces within the gallbladder wall.

Option D- Cholecystitis: Cholecystitis is inflammation of the gallbladder, usually caused by the obstruction of the cystic duct by gallstones. It often presents with severe right upper abdominal pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. In some cases, it can lead to complications such as gallbladder perforation or abscess formation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true for a 35-year-old patient with recurrent, itchy, blistering skin rashes on extensor surfaces, gastrointestinal symptoms after wheat consumption, granular IgA deposits in the dermal papillae, and elevated tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies?

choices.text: The skin lesions are primarily due to an allergic reaction to gluten in the diet.
The presence of tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies is indicative of a diagnosis of dermatitis herpetiformis alone.
IgG deposits in the skin are typically seen in this patient's condition.
The most likely HLA haplotype associated with this condition is HLA-DQ2

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The most likely HLA haplotype associated with this condition is HLA-DQ2:

  • This statement is correct. The majority of individuals with DH and celiac disease carry the HLA-DQ2 haplotype, with HLA-DQ8 being the other common haplotype. These HLA types are associated with an increased risk for developing these conditions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The skin lesions are primarily due to an allergic reaction to gluten in the diet: The skin lesions described are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis (DH), which is an autoimmune blistering skin condition closely associated with celiac disease. It's not primarily an allergic reaction but an autoimmune response to gluten consumption.

Option B - The presence of tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies is indicative of a diagnosis of dermatitis herpetiformis alone: While elevated levels of tissue transglutaminase (tTG) antibodies are common in DH, they are also indicative of celiac disease. DH is often considered the skin manifestation of celiac disease, and both conditions share common immunologic features, including tTG antibodies.

Option C - IgG deposits in the skin are typically seen in this patient's condition: IgA deposits, not IgG, are typically seen in the skin in dermatitis herpetiformis. IgA deposits in the dermal papillae are a hallmark feature of DH.

questions.text: In a 29-year-old who underwent Caesarean section and baby is delivered, what is the minimum amount of blood loss required for the diagnosis of Post partum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – 1000 mL:

  • PPH is defined as Any bleeding in the genital tract after delivery, not only uterine, includes traumatic and other causes too.

  • Traditionally > 500ml in normal delivery and > 1000 ml in a caesarean section.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic due to a history of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds. The boy's maternal grandfather had similar symptoms throughout his life. The family history also reveals that the boy's maternal uncle passed away in early childhood due to severe bleeding after minor injuries. The patient's parents, who are both healthy, are concerned about his health and potential bleeding disorder. What is the most likely mode of inheritance for this young boy's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 

  • This clinical scenario points toward X-linked recessive inheritance. The boy has a family history of males in the maternal lineage experiencing similar symptoms of easy bruising and severe bleeding. Specifically, the boy's maternal grandfather had similar symptoms throughout his life, and the maternal uncle passed away in early childhood due to severe bleeding after minor injuries. The fact that the males in the maternal lineage are affected, but the parents are healthy, strongly suggests X-linked recessive inheritance. In X-linked recessive conditions, males who inherit a single copy of the affected gene from their mothers (who are carriers) are at risk of developing the disorder. Females who are carriers typically do not exhibit symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 

  • Gonadal mosaicism: This is not the most likely mode of inheritance in this case. Gonadal mosaicism refers to genetic changes occurring in a subset of an individual's germ cells, which can result in a parent passing on a new mutation to their offspring. However, this scenario is better explained by X-linked recessive inheritance.

Option C - 

  • Mitochondrial inheritance: This type of inheritance is related to genes found in the mitochondria and is passed from mother to all her offspring. It does not appear to be the mode of inheritance in this case.

Option D - 

  • X-linked dominant inheritance: In X-linked dominant inheritance, both males and females can be affected, and affected individuals have a 50% chance of passing the condition to their offspring. This inheritance pattern does not align with the clinical presentation described in the scenario.

questions.text: A preterm newborn is delivered with Apgar scores of 3 at 1 minute and 6 at 5 minutes. During neonatal resuscitation, what should be the appropriate FiO2 for positive-pressure ventilation to improve oxygenation without causing hyperoxia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - FiO2 of 0.30 (30%)

  • Apgar scores of 3 at 1 minute and 6 at 5 minutes indicate that the newborn initially had significant distress but has shown improvement over time. During neonatal resuscitation, it is essential to provide appropriate oxygenation without causing hyperoxia, as hyperoxia can have adverse effects. A FiO2 of 0.30 (30%) is commonly recommended for positive-pressure ventilation during resuscitation to achieve the balance of oxygenation while avoiding hyperoxia.
  • In preterm <35 weeks of gestation begin resuscitation with low oxygen (21 to 30%). Further titration of oxygen depends on SpO2 response.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - FiO2 of 0.18 (18%): This choice represents room air, which has an oxygen concentration of 21%. Room air may not provide sufficient oxygenation, especially in a newborn with initial distress and low Apgar scores.

Option C - FiO2 of 0.40 (40%): While a higher FiO2 may provide more oxygen, it also increases the risk of hyperoxia, which can be harmful to the newborn. Hyperoxia can lead to oxidative stress and potential lung and eye complications in premature infants.

Option D - FiO2 of 0.50 (50%): Using an even higher FiO2 may further increase the risk of hyperoxia, which can have adverse effects on the newborn, including the risk of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) and other complications associated with excessive oxygen exposure.

questions.text: Which of the following are not included in the Diagnostic criteria of SIADH?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Urine Osmolarity decreased:

  • In SIADH, urine osmolarity is typically increased, not decreased. This is because the kidneys are unable to excrete excess water, resulting in concentrated urine. Therefore, decreased urine osmolarity is not consistent with the diagnostic criteria for SIADH.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Plasma osmolarity <275 mosm/Kg H2O: In the diagnostic criteria for Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH), one of the key features is a low plasma osmolarity, often defined as <275 mosm/Kg H2O.

Option B - Clinical euvolemia: Clinical euvolemia is another important component of the diagnostic criteria for SIADH. Patients with SIADH typically exhibit euvolemia, meaning they do not show signs of dehydration or excessive fluid overload.

Option D - Urine sodium >40 mmol/L: An elevated urine sodium concentration (>40 mmol/L) is often seen in SIADH. In this condition, the kidneys retain sodium, leading to increased levels of sodium in the urine.

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of the auditory pathway, from the initial reception of sound waves to the interpretation of auditory signals in the brain?

choices.text: Cochlear Nucleus → Superior Olivary Nucleus → Lateral Lemniscus → Inferior Colliculus → Medial Geniculate Nucleus → Primary Auditory Cortex
Cochlear Nucleus → Medial Geniculate Nucleus → Superior Olivary Nucleus → Inferior Colliculus → Lateral Lemniscus → Primary Auditory Cortex
Cochlear Nucleus → Lateral Lemniscus → Superior Olivary Nucleus → Inferior Colliculus → Medial Geniculate Nucleus → Primary Auditory Cortex
Cochlear Nucleus → Superior Olivary Nucleus → Inferior Colliculus → Lateral Lemniscus → Medial Geniculate Nucleus → Primary Auditory Cortex

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Cochlear Nucleus → Superior Olivary Nucleus → Lateral Lemniscus → Inferior Colliculus → Medial Geniculate Nucleus → Primary Auditory Cortex:

  • This sequential pathway ensures that auditory information undergoes progressive processing and analysis as it moves through various brain structures, from basic sound detection to more complex auditory perception. The brain processes and interprets auditory signals to provide us with the ability to hear, localize sounds, and comprehend the auditory environment around us.

Incorrect Options: 

Options B, C & D are incorrect sequence of auditory pathway

questions.text: A 3-day-old neonate is brought to the pediatric clinic by concerned parents. The baby was born full-term and appeared healthy at birth. However, in the past 24 hours, the parents have noticed that the infant's skin and eyes have developed a yellowish discoloration. The parents have also observed abnormal movements in the baby's limbs. On further assessment, it was discovered that the baby's maternal aunt experienced similar symptoms of jaundice and abnormal movements in her childhood, which eventually improved. What is the most likely part of the brain involved in this neonate's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Basal ganglia:

  • The clinical scenario suggests neonatal jaundice, which can lead to a condition known as bilirubin encephalopathy or kernicterus when bilirubin levels rise significantly. Kernicterus is characterized by the deposition of bilirubin in the brain and can lead to neurological symptoms. One of the common manifestations of kernicterus is the involvement of the basal ganglia, leading to abnormal movements and motor disorders. The basal ganglia plays a crucial role in motor control, and its damage due to bilirubin deposition can result in neurological deficits. Kernicterus typically affects the basal ganglia, leading to the motor symptoms observed in the neonate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cerebellum: The cerebellum plays a significant role in coordinating motor movements and balance. However, in neonatal jaundice-related encephalopathy (kernicterus), the characteristic motor abnormalities, such as hypertonia and dystonia, are primarily associated with damage to the basal ganglia rather than the cerebellum.

Option C - Hippocampus: The hippocampus is primarily associated with memory and spatial navigation functions. It is not typically involved in the motor abnormalities seen in kernicterus. Kernicterus is more related to bilirubin-induced damage to the basal ganglia, which controls motor functions.

Option D - Thalamus: The thalamus serves as a relay center for sensory information. While the thalamus plays a critical role in sensory processing, it is not the primary brain region associated with the motor abnormalities observed in neonatal jaundice-related encephalopathy (kernicterus).

questions.text:
Which of the following opportunistic infections or conditions are diagnostic criteria for AIDS according to the CDC definition, regardless of HIV serology, in a patient with compatible clinical manifestations?

A. Candida Oro-pharyngitis

B. Cerebral toxoplasmosis

C. Kaposi Sarcoma

D. CMV colitis

E. Mycobacterium Avium Intracellulare (MAI) infection
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - B, C, D, E:

  •  According to the CDC definition of AIDS, the presence of certain opportunistic infections or conditions is diagnostic for AIDS, regardless of HIV serology, if the patient has compatible clinical manifestations. These conditions include cerebral toxoplasmosis (B), Kaposi Sarcoma (C), CMV colitis (D), and Mycobacterium Avium Intracellulare (MAI) infection (E).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A and D: It includes Candida Oro-pharyngitis (A), which is an AIDS-defining condition. However, it does not include cerebral toxoplasmosis (B), Kaposi Sarcoma (C), or Mycobacterium Avium Intracellulare (MAI) infection (E), all of which are CDC-defined AIDS conditions.

Option B - B and E: It includes cerebral toxoplasmosis (B) and Mycobacterium Avium Intracellulare (MAI) infection (E), which are AIDS-defining conditions. However, it omits Kaposi Sarcoma (C) and CMV colitis (D), which are also CDC-defined AIDS conditions.

Option C - A, B, and D: It includes Candida Oro-pharyngitis (A), cerebral toxoplasmosis (B), and CMV colitis (D). While these are AIDS-related conditions, it omits Kaposi Sarcoma (C) and Mycobacterium Avium Intracellulare (MAI) infection (E), both of which are CDC-defined AIDS conditions.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the clinical features of the condition shown in the picture?




	B/L nasal obstruction
	Unilateral nasal obstruction
	Recurrent epistaxis
	Proptosis
	Headache
	Serous otitis media
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 2,3,4,6: The X-ray shows Holman Miller sign which is pathognomic of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma

2.Unilateral nasal obstruction - This is a common clinical feature of the condition shown in the picture. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) often leads to unilateral nasal obstruction due to its growth and location in the nasopharynx.

3. Recurrent epistaxis - Recurrent nosebleeds (epistaxis) are a characteristic clinical feature of JNA. The tumor is highly vascular, and its growth can lead to frequent nosebleeds.

4. Proptosis, or bulging of the eye, can occur in cases where JNA extends into the orbit and compresses surrounding structures.

6.Serous otitis media - JNA can lead to the development of serous otitis media, an ear condition that results from Eustachian tube obstruction, and is characterized by fluid accumulation in the middle ear.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A- 1,3,4: Bilateral (both sides) nasal obstruction is not a typical feature of JNA. JNA usually presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, primarily affecting one side. Statements 3, 4 are the clinical features of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma.

Option B - 2,3,4,5: contain 2, 3, 4 which are the clinical features of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma while Headache (5) can occur in cases where JNA extends into the intracranial space, it is not one of the more common or characteristic features. 

Option C- 1,3,4,6: contain 3, 4, 6 which are the clinical features of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma while Bilateral (both sides) nasal obstruction(1) is not a typical feature of JNA.

questions.text: Which of the following developmental milestones, when absent, suggests a developmental delay in a 2-year-old child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Kicking a ball:

  • The ability to kick a ball is a developmental milestone typically achieved around 2 years of age. It involves coordination, balance, and gross motor skills. If a 2-year-old child cannot kick a ball, it may suggest a developmental delay in their motor skills.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Copies a circle: Copies a circle is a more advanced motor skill that is typically achieved around 3 years of age.

Option C - Catching a ball: Catching a ball is another complex motor skill that children typically develop around 4 years of age. It involves hand-eye coordination and fine motor skills, which are beyond the developmental stage of a 2-year-old.

Option D - Building a tower of 9 cubes: Building a tower of 9 cubes is a fine motor skill that usually develops around 3 years of age, so its absence may not necessarily indicate a developmental delay at this age.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is NOT among the common indications for tracheostomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Emphysema:

  • Emphysema - Emphysema is NOT a common indication for tracheostomy. Emphysema is a chronic lung condition that primarily affects the lower airways, while tracheostomy is typically performed for upper airway issues or when lower airway issues result in respiratory insufficiency. Tracheostomy is not commonly performed to manage emphysema.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis is a potentially life-threatening condition that can lead to upper airway obstruction. Tracheostomy may be indicated in cases of acute epiglottitis to secure the airway.

Option B- Bilateral abductor paralysis: Bilateral abductor paralysis of the vocal cords can lead to severe airway obstruction, making tracheostomy necessary in some cases to ensure a patent airway.

Option D- Strychnine poisoning: Strychnine poisoning can cause severe muscle spasms, including those of the respiratory muscles, leading to respiratory distress and potential airway compromise. Tracheostomy may be required to maintain an open airway in cases of severe strychnine poisoning.

questions.text: A 32-year-old immunocompromised patient presents with respiratory symptoms, and a chest HRCT reveals ground glass opacities with cysts. β 1,3 glucan testing is ordered to identify the causative pathogen. Which of the following statements regarding the β 1,3 glucan test is false?

choices.text: It can help diagnose Pneumocystis jirovecii infection.
It is useful for distinguishing between colonization and infection in airways.
It is not effective in detecting mucormycosis in patients with diabetes mellitus.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It is useful for distinguishing between colonization and infection in airways:

  • The β 1,3 glucan test is primarily used to detect fungal infections by measuring the presence of a specific fungal cell wall component, β 1,3 glucan, in the bloodstream. However, it is not typically used to distinguish between colonization and active infection in the airways or elsewhere in the body. Instead, it is used to detect the presence of fungal pathogens in patients who may be at risk of fungal infections, particularly immunocompromised individuals.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It can help diagnose Pneumocystis jirovecii infection: The β 1,3 glucan test can be helpful in diagnosing Pneumocystis jirovecii infection, which is a fungal pathogen commonly associated with respiratory symptoms, especially in immunocompromised individuals.

Option B - It can identify Candida infections: The β 1,3 glucan test can identify Candida infections. Candida is a common fungal pathogen, and the test can help detect its presence in the bloodstream.

Option D - It is not effective in detecting mucormycosis in patients with diabetes mellitus: The β 1,3 glucan test is generally not effective in detecting mucormycosis, a fungal infection caused by molds of the order Mucorales. Mucormycosis is caused by a different type of fungal cell wall composition, and β 1,3 glucan is not a reliable marker for this type of infection. Patients with diabetes mellitus can be at increased risk for mucormycosis, and other diagnostic methods would be more suitable for detecting this infection.

questions.text: What is the value of lead II in Einthoven’s triangle, when Lead I is 2mV and Lead III is 1mV?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – 3:

  • Lead II potential = Lead I + Lead III potential, it is known as Einthoven law.
  • Lead II = Lead I + Lead III = 2 + 1 =3

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
A newborn infant is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit with respiratory distress shortly after birth. A chest X-ray revels the following :



Based on the chest X-ray image and clinical presentation, which genetic predisposition is most commonly associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)?

 


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			Down syndrome
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Turner syndrome
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Patau syndrome
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			Edwards syndrome
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 3,4:

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is most commonly associated with Patau syndrome and Edwards syndrome.

  • 3 - Trisomy 13, also known as Patau syndrome, is a chromosomal disorder caused by an extra copy of chromosome 13. This genetic condition is commonly associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). CDH in individuals with trisomy 13 often results from abnormalities in the development of the diaphragm during fetal development.
  • 4 -Trisomy 18, known as Edwards syndrome, is another chromosomal disorder characterized by an extra copy of chromosome 18. Like trisomy 13, this genetic condition is also commonly associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) (1, 3): Down syndrome is caused by an extra copy of chromosome 21, and it is not typically associated with CDH. While individuals with Down syndrome may have other congenital anomalies, CDH is not a common feature of this condition.

Option B - Turner syndrome (Monosomy X) (2, 4): Turner syndrome results from the absence of one X chromosome in females. CDH is not a common feature of Turner syndrome. This syndrome is more commonly associated with other congenital abnormalities, such as heart and kidney problems, but not CDH.

questions.text: A 47-year-old patient presents with a history of shortness of breath and is suspected of having a pulmonary pathology. A Spirometry is done and a spirogram is shown below. What is the inspiratory capacity in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C –  3.0:

  • Inspiratory capacity = Tidal volume + Inspiratory reserve volume = 1 + 2 = 3

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for a surgical procedure under general anesthesia. The anesthesia team decided to use a depolarizing muscle relaxant as part of the anesthesia induction process. Following the administration of succinylcholine, the patient quickly develops paralysis and undergoes intubation. However, a few minutes after the administration, the patient starts experiencing muscle fasciculations. Which of the following is the most likely cause of muscle fasciculations following the use of succinylcholine, and how should it be managed?

choices.text: Hypothermia; Warm intravenous fluids should be administered.
Hyperkalemia; Administer calcium gluconate and initiate measures to lower potassium levels.
Respiratory acidosis; Increase the ventilator settings to improve ventilation.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Hyperkalemia; Administer calcium gluconate and initiate measures to lower potassium levels:

  • The patient's muscle fasciculations following the administration of succinylcholine are a characteristic response to this depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Succinylcholine initially stimulates nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, causing depolarization and muscle fasciculations. However, these fasciculations can lead to an increase in intracellular potassium levels, as succinylcholine continues to stimulate the muscle, resulting in potassium efflux.
  • In some individuals, particularly those with a predisposition to hyperkalemia, this potassium efflux can be significant and lead to life-threatening levels of hyperkalemia. Hyperkalemia can cause cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular fibrillation, and other severe complications.
  • The correct management in this scenario involves addressing the hyperkalemia:
    1. Administering calcium gluconate to stabilize the cardiac membrane.
    2. Initiating measures to lower potassium levels, which may include administration of agents like sodium bicarbonate, insulin and glucose, and potassium-binding resins.
    3. Monitoring the patient's ECG and potassium levels closely.

Incorrect Options:

 

Option A. Hypothermia: Hypothermia is unlikely to cause muscle fasciculations in this context, and warming intravenous fluids would not be the primary treatment for this situation.

Option C. Respiratory acidosis: While succinylcholine can cause respiratory issues, it is unlikely to result in muscle fasciculations as the primary symptom, and simply increasing ventilator settings would not address the underlying problem.

Option D. Anaphylaxis: Anaphylaxis is characterized by a severe allergic reaction, which can include symptoms like rash, difficulty breathing, and shock. Muscle fasciculations are not a typical sign of anaphylaxis, and the treatment for anaphylaxis would primarily involve epinephrine and antihistamines to address the allergic reaction.

questions.text:

A. Contralateral motor loss

B. Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibration sense

C. Ipsilateral Impaired proprioception, fine, touch and two-point discrimination

D. Contralateral impaired pain and temperature sensation
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Only A:

  • In Brown Sequard syndrome, there is ipsilateral motor loss.
  • Symptoms of Brown Sequard syndrome is:
    • Ipsilateral Complete sensory loss.
    • Ipsilateral loss of joint position and vibration sense.
    • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sense.
    • Ipsilateral motor loss

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old child presents with recurrent, painful bone lesions. Physical examination reveals multiple lytic bone lesions on radiographs. The child also has skin rashes and enlarged lymph nodes. X-ray skull shows:



Which of the following microscopic findings is most likely to be observed on electron microscopy in cells from the bone lesions of this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Birbeck granules:

  • The clinical scenario and the punched out lesion on the skull points toward the diagnosis of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH), which is characterized by the presence of Birbeck granules on electron microscopy, which are rod-shaped or tennis racket-shaped organelles. These granules are considered specific to Langerhans cells, and their presence aids in the diagnosis of LCH.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lewy bodies: Lewy bodies are found in Parkinson's disease and Lewy body dementia.

Option C - Heinz bodies: Heinz bodies are seen in conditions like G6PD deficiency.

Option D - Howell-Jolly bodies: Howell-Jolly bodies are associated with splenic dysfunction or postsplenectomy conditions.

questions.text: Identify the given equipment:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Venturi mask:

  • The given equipment is a Venturi mask. Venturi masks are designed to deliver a specific fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) by mixing oxygen with room air in precise ratios. They are especially useful in situations where it's crucial to provide an accurate and controlled FiO2, such as in patients with specific respiratory needs or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). This allows healthcare providers to adjust the FiO2 to meet the patient's requirements more precisely.

questions.text: A parent with their 1-month-old baby comes to OPD with a complaint of inversion of the foot of their baby. An image is given below. Which is the correct sequence of its correction according to Kite’s philosophy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Adduction → Inversion → Equinus:

  • Order of correction according to Kite’s philosophy is Adduction deformity is corrected first followed by inversion deformity and then Equinus deformity.

  • The given case is suggestive of CTEV.

  • According to Kite’s philosophy, the foot is treated by manipulation and PoP beginning at the age of 1 month.

  • A below-knee plaster cast is usually sufficient.

  • The cast has to be changed every 2 weeks.

  • Usually, correction is achieved in 30% of cases over a period of 6-9 months.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D are incorrect Options.

questions.text: Which of the following shown in image below respond to sustained pressure and touch?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – 2:

  • The marked structure 2 is Merkel cells which respond to Sustained pressure and touch.
  • It Slowly adapts the signals.
  • Merkel discs are often grouped together in a receptor organ called the Iggo dome receptor, which projects upward against the underside of the epithelium of the skin.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A – 3:

  • The marked structure is the Meissner corpuscle.
  • It responds to:
    • Fine or light touch
    • Position sense
    • Low-frequency vibration

Option C – 1:

  • The marked structure is Krause’s corpuscle.
  • It aids in thermal sensation.

Option D – 4:

  • The marked structure is the Pacinian corpuscle.
  • It responds to high-frequency vibration and pressure.

questions.text: A 52-year-old menopausal female presented to OPD with complaints of Bone pain. X-ray is advised and given below. Which of the following drug is use to increase the Bone formation?
questions.solution:
Correct option A – Teriparatide:

  • Teriparatide is a medication used to increase bone formation.
  • It is a synthetic form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and helps to stimulate the bone formation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Bisphosphonates:

  • Bisphosphonates help to reduce the bone resorption.
  • They do not increase bone formation but rather help to maintain the bone density by slowing down the loss of bone.

Option C – Calcitonin:

  • It primarily inhibits the bone resorption.
  • It doesn’t have a direct role in increasing bone resorption.

Option D – Denosumab:

  • It is an anti-resorptive agent.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is scheduled for elective knee surgery and has opted for regional anesthesia. The anesthesia team plans to perform a central neuraxial blockade to provide anesthesia for this procedure. When discussing the choice of anesthetic agent, which medication is the most commonly used for central neuraxial blockade and is the first-line choice in this setting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Bupivacaine:

  • Bupivacaine is the most commonly used medication for central neuraxial blockade, making it the first-line choice in this setting. It is a long-acting local anesthetic that is frequently used in epidurals and spinal anesthesia. Bupivacaine provides excellent analgesia and sensory blockade, making it a preferred choice for procedures where prolonged pain relief is required.

Incorrect Options:

Options A-Ropivacaine - Ropivacaine is another long-acting local anesthetic that is often used in similar settings and is a suitable alternative to bupivacaine

Options B- Lidocaine -  Lidocaine is a shorter-acting local anesthetic and is more commonly used for peripheral nerve blocks

Options D-Prilocaine - Prilocaine is another local anesthetic but is not as commonly used as bupivacaine and ropivacaine for central neuraxial blockade.

questions.text: Which of the following inhibit the growth hormone secretion except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Ghrelin:

  • Ghrelin stimulates the growth hormone secretion.
  • The following factors inhibit the growth hormone secretion:
    • Increased blood glucose
    • Increased blood free fatty acids
    • Aging
    • Obesity
    • Somatostatin
    • Growth hormone (Exogenous)
    • Somatomedins

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C are incorrect.

  • As all of them inhibit the growth hormone secretion

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is scheduled for surgery on the forearm under regional anesthesia with an axillary nerve block. The procedure is uneventful, and the patient experiences adequate anesthesia throughout the surgery. After the surgery, the patient is in the recovery area. However, there is concern about the patient's inability to extend the forearm and the loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm and hand. What is the most likely cause of the patient's inability to extend the forearm and the loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm and hand after an axillary nerve block?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Radial nerve injury:

  • The axillary nerve block primarily affects the axillary nerve, which is a branch of the radial nerve. This nerve provides motor innervation to the deltoid muscle (responsible for shoulder abduction) and sensory innervation to the skin over the lateral aspect of the upper arm. It does not directly innervate the forearm or hand muscles, but it does contribute to the innervation of the lateral aspect of the forearm and hand through its radial nerve connection.
  • In the case of an axillary nerve block, injury to the axillary nerve can result in the inability to extend the forearm (especially at the elbow joint) due to the loss of innervation to the triceps muscle, which is primarily responsible for this movement. Additionally, there will be a loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm and hand, as the axillary nerve and its branches provide sensory input to these areas through the radial nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect

  • Ulnar, median, and musculocutaneous nerves are not typically affected by an axillary nerve block, and brachial plexus injury would result in a broader range of neurological deficits in the entire upper limb, not just the lateral aspect of the forearm and hand.

questions.text: A 25-year-old has presented to OPD with a complaint of weakness in fingers of his right hand. On performing the book test, there is flexion at the interphalangeal joint. This cause from Injury to which of the following structure as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 2:

  • The book test or froment’s sign is done to check the Adductor pollicis muscle.
  • Which is suppled by the Deep branch of the ulnar nerve in the hand. So, the ulnar nerve is the correct Option.
  • Normally, a person will grasp the book firmly with his thumb extended and with the help of adductor pollicis and the first dorsal interosseus muscles.
  • If the ulnar nerve gets injured, the adductor pollicis is paralyzed and the the patient will hold the Book by using the flexor pollicis longus in place of adductor.
  • As it produces the flexion at the interphalangeal joint of thumb.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- 3:

  • The marked structure is the biceps brachi muscle which is irrelevant to ulnar nerve.

Option B – 4:

  • The marked structure is brachial artery.

Option C – 1:

  • The marked structure is the median nerve.
  • To check the median nerve injury there are few clinical tests can be done:
    • Pen test
    • Ape thumb deformity test
    • Ochsner’s clasp test

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presents to her primary care physician with complaints of severe fatigue, weakness, and pale skin. She reports heavy menstrual bleeding and a decline in weight from 48kg to 46kg in the past 3 months. Her physical examination reveals conjunctival pallor, glossitis, and brittle nails. Her haemoglobin is 6.8gm/dL and a peripheral blood smear reveals:



How much total iron is required for her intravenous treatment as per the ganzoni formula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1.37 gm:

  • The Ganzoni formula to calculate the total iron required for intravenous treatment in a patient with iron deficiency anemia is as follows:
  • Total iron needed (mg) = (Body weight [kg] × (15 - Hb [g/dL]) × 2.3) + 500 mg
  • For this patient :
  • Body weight = 46 kg
  • Hemoglobin (Hb) = 6.8 g/dL
  • Total iron needed = (46 kg × (15 - 6.8 g/dL) × 2.3) + 500 mg
  • Total iron needed = (46 kg × 8.2 g/dL × 2.3) + 500 mg
  • Total iron needed = 867.56 + 500 mg
  • Total iron needed = 1367.56 mg ≈ 1.37 gm

questions.text: Which of the following correctly matched Hormone with their signaling pathways:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IGF-1 – Receptor tyrosine kinase:

  • IGF-1 (Insulin-like Growth Factor 1) signals through a receptor tyrosine kinase pathway.
  • When IGF-1 binds to its receptor, it activates receptor tyrosine kinases, leading to the phosphorylation of tyrosine residues in the receptor itself and downstream signaling proteins.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Insulin – IP3:

  • Insulin primarily signals through the Receptor tyrosine kinase, not IP3 (Inositol trisphosphate). This pathway plays a crucial role in regulating glucose uptake and metabolism in cells.

Option B – Oxytocin - cAMP:

  • Oxytocin signals through IP3 not through cAMP.

Option D – FSH – cGMP:

  • FSH primarily signals through cAMP.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the disease associated with picture given is correct ?

choices.text: Face of Panda appearance is seen on MRI
KF rings with hepatic manifestations are having diagnostic accuracy of 95-98%
Dysarthria is not a common manifestation of this disease

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Face of Panda appearance is seen on MRI:

  • The correct statement is that the disease associated with the given picture is characterized by the "Face of Panda" appearance on MRI. This description is typically associated with Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder characterized by abnormal copper metabolism. The "Face of Panda" appearance refers to bilateral hyperintensities in the basal ganglia seen on T2-weighted MRI images, which is a characteristic finding in Wilson's disease.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Associated with ATP 7 a gene: Wilson's disease is indeed associated with mutations in the ATP7B gene, not ATP7a. Mutations in the ATP7B gene lead to impaired copper transport, resulting in the accumulation of copper in various tissues, including the liver and brain.

Option C - KF rings with hepatic manifestations are having diagnostic accuracy of 95-98%: While Kayser-Fleischer (KF) rings, which are copper deposits in the cornea, are a characteristic finding in Wilson's disease, they alone are not considered highly accurate for diagnosis. The diagnosis of Wilson's disease typically relies on a combination of clinical, biochemical, and genetic testing in addition to the presence of KF rings.

Option D - Dysarthria is not a common manifestation of this disease: Dysarthria, a speech disorder characterized by difficulty in articulating words, can be a common manifestation of Wilson's disease. This is due to the neurological effects of copper buildup in the brain, which can lead to various neurological symptoms, including dysarthria.

questions.text: Which of the following condition is associated with the given ECG :
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ebstein's anomaly:

  • The ECG finding reveal a "Himalayan P wave" pattern which is typically associated with Ebstein anomaly. Ebstein anomaly is a rare congenital heart defect where the tricuspid valve is abnormally positioned and often leads to enlarged right atrium. This enlargement can cause a characteristic ECG pattern known as a "Himalayan P wave," which is a tall and broad P wave in lead II.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tetralogy of Fallot: Tetralogy of Fallot is a cyanotic congenital heart defect characterized by four specific heart abnormalities: pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. ECG findings show right ventricular hypertrophy.

Option B - Transposition of the Great Arteries: Transposition of the Great Arteries is another congenital heart condition where the aorta and the pulmonary artery are switched. The ECG findings for this condition usually reflect right ventricular hypertrophy.

Option D - Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome: Hypoplastic Left Heart Syndrome is a severe congenital heart defect in which the left side of the heart is underdeveloped. ECG findings show signs of left ventricular underdevelopment and right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient has been using proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) for the management of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) for several years. In this patient, due to long-term PPI use, which of the following secretions from which cells is most likely to be increased as a compensatory response?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – G cells:

  • G cells are responsible for secreting gastrin, a hormone that stimulates gastric acid (HCl) secretion by the parietal cells in the stomach.

  • When a patient uses proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), such as omeprazole or lansoprazole, for an extended period, it reduces stomach acid production.

  • In response to the decrease in gastric acid, G cells can become more active and secrete increased levels of gastrin to stimulate acid production.

  • This is a compensatory mechanism the body employs when acid production is inhibited.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - S cells:

  • S cells secrete secretin, which primarily regulates the secretion of bicarbonate (HCO3-) from the pancreas and inhibits gastric acid production.

  • Long-term PPI use typically reduces the need for increased secretion of secretin.

Option C - D cells:

  • D cells secrete somatostatin, which inhibits the release of various hormones, including gastrin.

  • They act to suppress gastric acid secretion rather than increase it.

Option D - I cells:

  • I cells, also known as enteroendocrine cells, secrete cholecystokinin (CCK).

  • CCK is responsible for stimulating the gallbladder to release bile and promoting pancreatic enzyme secretion. It does not have a direct role in gastric acid secretion.

questions.text:
Assertion: In patients with chronic hepatitis B, the presence of HBsAg is always indicative of ongoing viral replication.

Reason: HBsAg, as the earliest serological marker in hepatitis B infection, persists for a long time in chronic hepatitis B, signifying ongoing viral replication and infectivity.

choices.text: Both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion.
Both the assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion.
The assertion is true, but the reason is false.
The assertion is false, but the reason is true

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Both the assertion and reason are true, but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion:

  • The assertion correctly states that in patients with chronic hepatitis B, the presence of HBsAg is always indicative of ongoing viral replication.
  • The reason accurately states that HBsAg, as the earliest serological marker in hepatitis B infection, persists for a long time in chronic hepatitis B and signifies ongoing viral replication and infectivity.
  • However, the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion. The presence of HBsAg, while indicating ongoing viral infection, doesn't directly mean that replication is occurring. HBsAg can persist even without active viral replication in some chronic cases.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Both the assertion and reason are true, and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion: The presence of HBsAg doesn't always directly imply ongoing viral replication. Therefore, the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.

Option C - The assertion is true, but the reason is false: Both the assertion and reason are true. The reason is a valid statement but doesn't serve as the correct explanation for the assertion.

Option D - The assertion is false, but the reason is true: Both the assertion and reason are true The presence of HBsAg is indeed associated with ongoing viral infection, though the reason doesn't fully explain the assertion.

questions.text: In a child with Alport syndrome, what is the most common ocular manifestation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Anterior lenticonus:

  • Anterior lenticonus is a common ocular manifestation of Alport syndrome. It is characterized by conical bulging or thinning of the front portion of the eye's lens (the anterior lens capsule). This condition can lead to visual disturbances and may require ophthalmological management.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Retinal detachment: While Alport syndrome can lead to various ocular issues, retinal detachment is not the most common manifestation. Retinal issues can occur but are less frequent than anterior lenticonus.

Option B - Cataracts: Cataracts can occur in individuals with Alport syndrome, but they are not the most common ocular manifestation. Cataracts involve clouding of the lens, which is different from the conical shape seen in anterior lenticonus.

Option C - Myopia: Myopia (nearsightedness) can be associated with Alport syndrome but is also less common than anterior lenticonus as the primary ocular manifestation. Myopia is a refractive error where distant objects appear blurry, and it may not always be present in individuals with Alport syndrome.

questions.text: Correct order of performing the test given in image is?

choices.text: Obliterate both the radial artery and ulnar artery, ask the patient to form a fist, release the ulnar artery first, and take the ABG sample from the radial artery.
Ask the patient to form a fist, palpate the artery between the tendon of flexor carpi radialis and styloid process, obliterate both arteries, and release both arteries simultaneously.
Obliterate both arteries, ask the patient to form a fist, release both arteries simultaneously, and check for pallor in the entire palm.

Palpate the artery between the tendon of flexor carpi radialis and styloid process, ask the patient to form a fist, obliterate both the radial and ulnar arteries, and take the ABG sample from the ulnar artery.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Obliterate both arteries, ask the patient to form a fist, release both arteries simultaneously, and check for pallor in the entire palm:

  • The correct sequence of steps to perform the Modified Allen test is as follows:
  1. Obliterate both arteries (radial and ulnar).
  2. Ask the patient to form a fist.
  3. The entire palm becomes pale due to arterial occlusion.
  4. Release both arteries simultaneously.
  5. If collaterals are present, the whole hand will have a blush from the release of either artery.
  6. Always take the ABG sample from where the collaterals are present, preferably the radial artery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A  - Obliterate both the radial artery and ulnar artery, ask the patient to form a fist, release the ulnar artery first, and take the ABG sample from the radial artery: This option incorrectly suggests releasing the ulnar artery first, which is not the standard practice for the Modified Allen test. Releasing both arteries simultaneously is the correct procedure to assess collateral circulation.

Option B - Ask the patient to form a fist, palpate the artery between the tendon of flexor carpi radialis and styloid process, obliterate both arteries, and release both arteries simultaneously: This option has the incorrect sequence of steps. It asks the patient to form a fist before the arteries are obliterated, which is not the correct order of the test. Palpating the artery is also introduced in the wrong place in the sequence.

Option D - Palpate the artery between the tendon of flexor carpi radialis and styloid process, ask the patient to form a fist, obliterate both the radial and ulnar arteries, and take the ABG sample from the ulnar artery: This option suggests taking the ABG sample from the ulnar artery, which is not the preferred site for ABG sampling in the Modified Allen test. The correct site is the radial artery. Additionally, the order of the steps is incorrect, as it suggests palpating the artery after asking the patient to form a fist, which is not the standard procedure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient with a history of asthma presents to the clinic with concerns about their current asthma management. They've been using salbutamol (SABA) for quick relief of symptoms for several years. Which of the following statements regarding the use of SABA in adults aligns with the updated GINA guidelines?

choices.text: SABA is a highly effective and recommended sole treatment for asthma symptoms in adults.
GINA recommends SABA as a sole treatment for newly diagnosed asthma in adults due to its rapid action.
SABA should not be used as the sole treatment for asthma in adults as it is associated with an increased risk of asthma-related death and healthcare emergencies.
SABA can be safely used as a sole treatment for asthma in adults if taken regularly

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - SABA should not be used as the sole treatment for asthma in adults as it is associated with an increased risk of asthma-related death and healthcare emergencies:

  • This statement aligns with the updated GINA guidelines. The guidelines recommend that SABA (Salbutamol) should not be used as the sole treatment for asthma in adults. This is because SABA, while effective for quick relief of symptoms, is associated with an increased risk of asthma-related death and healthcare emergencies, as stated in the updated guidelines.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - SABA is a highly effective and recommended sole treatment for asthma symptoms in adults: This option is incorrect because it states that SABA is a highly effective and recommended sole treatment for asthma symptoms in adults. However, the updated GINA guidelines do not recommend SABA as a sole treatment for asthma in adults.

Option B - GINA recommends SABA as a sole treatment for newly diagnosed asthma in adults due to its rapid action: This option is incorrect because it suggests that GINA recommends SABA as a sole treatment for newly diagnosed asthma in adults due to its rapid action. In fact, the updated guidelines advise against the use of SABA as the sole treatment for asthma, even in newly diagnosed cases.

Option D - SABA can be safely used as a sole treatment for asthma in adults if taken regularly: This option is incorrect because it implies that SABA can be safely used as a sole treatment for asthma in adults if taken regularly. This contradicts the updated GINA guidelines, which discourage the use of SABA as a sole treatment for asthma in adults, whether taken regularly or not. The guidelines emphasize the importance of alternative treatment approaches.

questions.text: In an emergency, a patient with RSA is presented. On examination, there is a Dirty wound with extensive soft tissue loss and bone is visible. On X-ray, there is a communicated fracture of the femur. According to Modified Gustilo and Anderson's classification the patient lies in which type?

Option B – IIIa:

  • Type IIIa consists of:

Option D – IIIc:

  • Type IIIc consists of:
    • High energy injury involving extensive Soft tissue damage.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old female presents with complaints of cola-colored urine, hypertension, and worsening renal function. Laboratory investigations reveal hematuria with dysmorphic red blood cells, low C3 levels, and elevated creatinine and BUN. A renal biopsy is performed, and the immunofluorescence image is shown below.



What is seen in the immunofluorescence image in this patient?

choices.text: IgG deposition - Lupus nephritis, characteristic feature: IgG, IgA, and IgM deposition
IgA deposition - IgA nephropathy, characteristic feature: IgA deposition
IgM deposition - Membranous nephropathy, characteristic feature: IgM deposition
IgG, IgA, and IgM deposition - Lupus nephritis, characteristic feature: Full house effect

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - IgG, IgA, and IgM deposition - Lupus nephritis, characteristic feature: Full house effect:

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IgG deposition - Lupus nephritis, characteristic feature: IgG, IgA, and IgM deposition: While IgG deposition is seen in lupus nephritis, it is not the only immunoglobulin involved. IgA and IgM depositions are also characteristic of lupus nephritis, leading to the full house effect.

Option B - IgA deposition - IgA nephropathy, characteristic feature: IgA deposition: IgA deposition is a specific feature of IgA nephropathy, not lupus nephritis. In IgA nephropathy, only IgA is deposited, not IgG or IgM.

Option C - IgM deposition - Membranous nephropathy, characteristic feature: IgM deposition: IgM deposition is a characteristic feature of membranous nephropathy, not lupus nephritis. In membranous nephropathy, IgM is deposited along the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presented to the emergency department with a contusion occurs 3 days ago. Which of the following colour of contusion and due to which pigment is seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Blue, Deoxyhemoglobin:

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Brown, Hemosiderin: On 4th day the contusion colour is brown due the hemosiderin pigment.

Option B - Red, Oxyhemoglobin: Initially the colour is red due to the oxyhemoglobin.

Option D - Yellow, Bilirubin: The colour yellow of contusion due to bilirubin seen on 7th to 12th day.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with newly diagnosed Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APML) started on all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA) and arsenic trioxide develops a constellation of symptoms, including fever, weight gain, dyspnea, and pulmonary infiltrates. Which of the following statements regarding this condition, often seen in APML patients during treatment, is accurate?

choices.text: This condition is known as Differentiation Syndrome (DS) and is primarily characterized by an increase in leukemic blasts.
Differentiation Syndrome occurs due to the overproduction of red blood cells in response to ATRA and arsenic trioxide.
Treatment for Differentiation Syndrome typically involves discontinuing ATRA and administering high-dose corticosteroids.
This syndrome is most commonly associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and is rarely seen in APML patients

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Treatment for Differentiation Syndrome typically involves discontinuing ATRA and administering high-dose corticosteroids:

  • This statement accurately describes Differentiation Syndrome (DS) in APML. DS is often seen in APML patients during treatment with ATRA and arsenic trioxide. It is characterized by symptoms such as fever, weight gain, dyspnea, and pulmonary infiltrates. Treatment for DS typically involves discontinuing ATRA and administering high-dose corticosteroids to manage the inflammatory response associated with DS.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - This condition is known as Differentiation Syndrome (DS) and is primarily characterized by an increase in leukemic blasts: This statement is incorrect. Differentiation Syndrome is not primarily characterized by an increase in leukemic blasts. Instead, it is characterized by the proliferation and differentiation of promyelocytes, leading to clinical manifestations such as fever, respiratory distress, and weight gain.

Option B - Differentiation Syndrome occurs due to the overproduction of red blood cells in response to ATRA and arsenic trioxide: This statement is inaccurate. Differentiation Syndrome in APML is not related to the overproduction of red blood cells in response to ATRA and arsenic trioxide. It is more associated with the differentiation of immature myeloid cells.

Option D - This syndrome is most commonly associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and is rarely seen in APML patients: This statement is incorrect. Differentiation Syndrome is not most commonly associated with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). It is a well-known complication in patients with Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APML) during treatment with ATRA and arsenic trioxide, and it is not a feature of CML.

questions.text: Which region of the internal capsule is responsible for the manifestation of left-sided hemiparesis in a 50-year-old male patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Posterior limb:

  • The posterior limb of the internal capsule contains the corticospinal tract, which is responsible for motor control of the limbs. Damage to this area can lead to contralateral hemiparesis, as seen in the patient's left-sided weakness.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Retrolentiform: Damage to the retrolentiform part of the internal capsule would typically result in sensory deficits, such as loss of sensation or abnormal sensation, rather than hemiparesis.

Option B - Sublentiform: Similar to the retrolentiform part, damage to the sublentiform part of the internal capsule is more likely to produce sensory deficits rather than hemiparesis.

Option C - Anterior limb: Damage to the anterior limb of the internal capsule can cause a variety of symptoms, including contralateral weakness, but it usually affects the face more than the limbs. Therefore, it is less likely to be the cause of the isolated left-sided hemiparesis described in the scenario

questions.text: Identify the conduction abnormality from the ECG given below
questions.solution:
Correct Option - A: Complete Heart Block:

  • The description accurately identifies complete heart block based on the ECG findings. These include a prolonged PR interval, a broad QRS complex, and a discrepancy between the number of P waves and R waves, with more P waves present. Additionally, the P-P interval does not match the R-R interval, indicating a complete dissociation between the atria and ventricles, characteristic of complete heart block.

Incorrect Options:

Options B - Second degree Heart Block: Second-degree heart block is characterized by intermittent blockage of atrioventricular conduction, leading to skipped QRS complexes. The ECG in the question does not exhibit this pattern; instead, it shows a continuous and constant blockage of conduction, which is indicative of complete heart block.

Option C - First degree Heart Block: First-degree heart block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval, but it does not involve a complete block of atrioventricular conduction. The ECG in the question displays a complete block, making it incompatible with first-degree heart block.

Option D - Atrial fibrillation: Atrial fibrillation is a chaotic and irregular rhythm characterized by the absence of distinct P waves and irregular R-R intervals. The ECG in the question does not exhibit the irregularity typical of atrial fibrillation. Instead, it shows a regular pattern with a fixed blockage, which is characteristic of complete heart block.

questions.text:
During a post-mortem examination of a 29-year-old male. The body recovered from the river. Which of the following findings are suggestive of Freshwater drowning?

A. Haemodilution

B. Hypernatremia

C. RBC lysis

D. Hyperkalaemia
questions.solution:
Correct Options C - A, C and D:

  • In Fresh water drowning,
    • Hypotonic fluid→ Pulmonary Capillaries → Haemodilution.
    • To neutralize fluid, RBCs are lysed and liberate K+ causing Hyperkalaemia.
    • Hyperkalaemia causes ventricular fibrillation → Cardiac arrest.
    • Fatal period is 5 min.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical findings is characteristic of aortic regurgitation?

choices.text: Systolic blood pressure increased due to increased stroke volume.
Diastolic blood pressure increases with aortic recoil.
A difference of more than 20 mm Hg in blood pressure between upper and lower limbs, known as Hill sign.
Systolic thrill felt at the left lower sternal border during auscultation

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A difference of more than 20 mm Hg in blood pressure between upper and lower limbs, known as Hill sign:

  • A characteristic clinical finding of aortic regurgitation is the Hill sign. This sign indicates a significant difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower limbs, typically greater than 20 mm Hg. It is due to the regurgitation of blood from the aorta back into the left ventricle during diastole, leading to a decrease in diastolic blood pressure in the upper limbs compared to the lower limbs. The Hill sign is an important diagnostic clue for aortic regurgitation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Systolic blood pressure increased due to increased stroke volume: This statement is incorrect. In aortic regurgitation, systolic blood pressure may actually be decreased because of the reduced diastolic blood pressure, leading to a wide pulse pressure (the difference between systolic and diastolic pressure).

Option B - Diastolic blood pressure increases with aortic recoil: This statement is also incorrect. In aortic regurgitation, diastolic blood pressure decreases as blood flows back into the left ventricle during diastole, resulting in decreased diastolic pressure.

Option D - Systolic thrill felt at the left lower sternal border during auscultation: While a systolic thrill is a clinical sign, it is typically associated with aortic stenosis rather than aortic regurgitation. In aortic regurgitation, a diastolic murmur and a wide pulse pressure are more characteristic features.

questions.text: In a 55-year-old male with angina-like chest pain, hypertension, and ECG findings of downsloping ST segment depression during physical activity and emotional stress, which noncardiac condition can the preferred medication also be utilized for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Migraine prophylaxis:

  • The drug of choice given the patient's clinical scenario of chest pain with downsloping ST segment depression on ECG is a beta-blocker.
  • The drug of choice given in the above condition, which is chronic stable angina, is likely a beta-blocker like Metoprolol. Beta-blockers are commonly used to manage angina by reducing the workload on the heart and decreasing the heart's oxygen demand.
  • Migraine prophylaxis is a noncardiac use of beta-blockers. These medications are also effective in reducing the frequency and severity of migraine headaches in some patients. Beta-blockers work by blocking the action of certain chemicals in the body that can trigger migraines.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Treatment of Erectile Dysfunction: The drug of choice given the patient's clinical scenario is a beta-blocker, which is used for its cardiac effects to manage angina (chest pain). Erectile dysfunction drugs like sildenafil (Viagra) or tadalafil (Cialis) are phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitors. These drugs work by increasing blood flow to the penis, which helps in achieving and maintaining an erection. They have no direct role in the treatment of angina or cardiac conditions.

Option C - Treatment of Allergic Rhinitis: Allergic rhinitis is an inflammatory condition of the nose caused by an allergic response to airborne allergens. Drugs used to treat allergic rhinitis include antihistamines (e.g., loratadine, cetirizine) and intranasal corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone, mometasone). These medications are not used in the management of angina or cardiac conditions, as they have no effect on the heart or blood vessels.

Option D - Treatment of Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD): The drug of choice given the patient's clinical scenario is a beta-blocker, not a drug used for GERD. The treatment of GERD typically involves the use of proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) like omeprazole, H2 blockers like ranitidine, or antacids to reduce stomach acid production or neutralize acid in the stomach. These drugs have no direct role in the treatment of angina or cardiac conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following about the management of High Altitude Pulmonary Edema is correct?

choices.text: Supplemental oxygen is first line of treatment
Crackles in the lower zone of lungs are heard
Nifedepine is used to prevent acute mountain sickness
If immediate descent is not possible, then the Gammow bag can help

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - If immediate descent is not possible, then the Gamow bag can help:

  • High Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE) is a serious medical condition that can occur at high altitudes when there is insufficient oxygen in the atmosphere. The Gamow bag, also known as a portable hyperbaric chamber, is a device used as a form of treatment for altitude sickness, including HAPE. It works by increasing the air pressure around the affected individual, which can help relieve the symptoms of altitude sickness, including HAPE, and provide temporary relief until descent to lower altitudes is possible. So, the statement that the Gamow bag can help if immediate descent is not possible is correct.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Supplemental oxygen is first line of treatment: Supplemental oxygen is indeed an essential part of the treatment for HAPE. However, it may not be considered the first-line treatment. Immediate descent to lower altitudes is the primary and most effective treatment for HAPE, as it rapidly increases oxygen levels and relieves the condition. While supplemental oxygen can be used as a supportive measure to improve oxygenation, it is not the primary or first-line treatment for HAPE.

Option B - Crackles in the lower zone of lungs are heard: Crackles are typically heard in the upper lung zones, not the lower lung zones, in cases of HAPE. The accumulation of fluid in the alveoli (small air sacs) of the upper parts of the lungs leads to crackles on auscultation. Crackles in the lower zones would be more indicative of conditions other than HAPE.

Option C - Nifedipine is used to prevent acute mountain sickness: Nifedipine is not primarily used to prevent acute mountain sickness (AMS). AMS is characterized by symptoms like headache, nausea, and fatigue that can occur at high altitudes. Medications like acetazolamide are often used to prevent and treat AMS, but nifedipine is more commonly associated with the prevention and treatment of HAPE, not AMS.

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is NOT associated with Myasthenia Gravis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Anti- casper 1 Antibodies:

  • Anti- casper 1 antibodies are not associated with Myasthenia Gravis (MG). Myasthenia Gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue. While the condition is often associated with the presence of specific autoantibodies, Anti- casper 1 antibodies are not a recognized component of MG.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anti-AChR Antibodies: Anti-Acetylcholine Receptor (Anti-AChR) antibodies are commonly associated with Myasthenia Gravis. These antibodies target the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to impaired nerve signal transmission and muscle weakness.

Option B - Anti-MuSK Antibodies: Anti-Muscle-Specific Kinase (Anti-MuSK) antibodies are another type of autoantibody associated with Myasthenia Gravis. They are found in a subset of MG patients and play a role in the pathogenesis of the disease by affecting neuromuscular junction function.

Option D - Anti-LRP4 Antibodies: Anti-LRP4 (Low-Density Lipoprotein Receptor-Related Protein 4) antibodies have also been identified in some cases of Myasthenia Gravis. LRP4 is a protein involved in neuromuscular junction development and function. Anti-LRP4 antibodies can contribute to the pathology of MG by interfering with neuromuscular transmission

questions.text: Which of the following regarding facilitated diffusion is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Requires carrier protein:

  • Facilitated diffusion is a passive transport process that allows molecules to move across the cell membrane down their concentration gradient.
  • Carrier proteins in the membrane facilitate this movement by binding to specific molecules and assisting their transport across the membrane.
  • These carrier proteins are essential for the process but do not require energy to transport the molecules.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Require energy for the transport:

  • Facilitated diffusion is a passive process and does not require energy. It relies on the inherent kinetic energy of the molecules and the assistance of carrier proteins.

Option B - Form of active transport:

  • Facilitated diffusion is not a form of active transport, as active transport processes require the input of energy to move molecules against their concentration gradient.

Option D - Does not follow saturation kinetics:

  • Facilitated diffusion can follow saturation kinetics, especially when all available carrier proteins are in use (the process is saturated). When all carrier proteins are bound to their substrates, the rate of facilitated diffusion reaches its maximum, and the process becomes saturated.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old male with persistent low back pain for 3 months, worsened at night but improved with physical activity or a hot bath, and accompanied by tenderness at the sacroiliac joint and buttock muscle atrophy, along with difficulty in lateral bending and touching the knees, what is the most likely HLA associated with the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A -  HLA-B27:

  • HLA-B27 is strongly associated with ankylosing spondylitis, a condition that matches the clinical presentation described in the question. Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of seronegative spondyloarthropathy characterized by inflammatory back pain, particularly in the sacroiliac joints. It typically worsens at night and improves with activity or heat, and it can lead to ankylosis (fusion) of the spine. The association of HLA-B27 with ankylosing spondylitis is well-established, making it the most likely HLA associated with the condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - HLA-DR4: HLA-DR4 is more commonly associated with autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis, not ankylosing spondylitis. Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects the joints of the hands, wrists, and other synovial joints and does not typically involve the sacroiliac joints.

Option C  - HLA-DQ2: HLA-DQ2 is primarily associated with celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder characterized by gluten intolerance and gastrointestinal symptoms. It is not the relevant HLA association for the described clinical presentation of low back pain and sacroiliac joint involvement.

Option D - HLA-DR2: HLA-DR2 is linked to various autoimmune diseases, including multiple sclerosis and systemic lupus erythematosus, but it is not the primary HLA association for the condition described in the question, which aligns more with ankylosing spondylitis and HLA-B27.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding the management of the condition shown by the ECG is incorrect?

choices.text: Rate control is the preferred strategy in patients with significant symptoms.
Antiarrhythmic drugs like amiodarone can be used for rhythm control in some cases.
Electrical cardioversion is the first-line treatment for all patients- of this condition.
This condition patients with a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 0 do not require anticoagulation therapy.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Electrical cardioversion is the first-line treatment for all patients of this condition:

  • In the case of atrial fibrillation (AF), electrical cardioversion is not the first-line treatment for all patients. Electrical cardioversion is typically reserved for patients with recent-onset AF or those who are hemodynamically unstable. The choice of treatment for AF depends on various factors, including the patient's clinical presentation, the duration of AF, underlying comorbidities, and the presence of symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rate control is the preferred strategy in patients with significant symptoms: Rate control is often the preferred strategy in patients with significant symptoms due to AF. It aims to control the heart rate to a more normal range and alleviate symptoms such as palpitations and fatigue.

Option B - Antiarrhythmic drugs like amiodarone can be used for rhythm control in some cases: Antiarrhythmic drugs, including amiodarone, can be used for rhythm control in some cases, especially when the goal is to restore and maintain normal sinus rhythm.

Option D - Patients with a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 0 do not require anticoagulation therapy: Anticoagulation therapy is recommended for AF patients based on their risk factors, as assessed by the CHA2DS2-VASc score. Even patients with a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 0 may still require anticoagulation if they have other risk factors such as being female, age 65-74, or the presence of vascular disease. The CHA2DS2-VASc score helps determine the need for anticoagulation to prevent stroke in AF patients.

Incorrect Options:

questions.text: Which of the following statements about CPR is correct?

choices.text: Sternum should go down by 7 cm
Place the hands on the upper 1/3rd of the sternum
Most common injured solid organ in CPR is liver
In neonatal ressucitation 1 rescuer is enough

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The most common injured solid organ in CPR is the liver:

  • During CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation), most common injured solid organ in CPR is liver (not lungs) as lungs are not a solid organ.
  • Most common ribs fractured during CPR- 4th to 6th

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sternum should go down by 7 cm: During CPR, the recommended depth of chest compressions for adults is approximately 5 to 6 centimeters (2 to 2.4 inches), not 7 cm. Excessive compression depth can lead to potential complications.

Option B - Place the hands on the upper 1/3rd of the sternum: During adult CPR, the recommended hand placement is in the center of the chest, on the lower half of the sternum, not the upper 1/3rd. Proper hand placement is essential for effective chest compressions.

Option D - In neonatal resuscitation, 1 rescuer is enough: In neonatal resuscitation, it is generally recommended to have at least 2 healthcare providers present, with one person responsible for providing chest compressions and another person handling ventilation (such as providing breaths through a bag-mask device). Neonatal resuscitation often requires a team effort to ensure the best outcomes for the infant. One rescuer alone is typically not enough.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects is the least likely to be caused by atropine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Diarrhea:

  • Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that blocks the action of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter responsible for various bodily functions, including stimulation of smooth muscles in the gastrointestinal tract. By blocking the effects of acetylcholine, atropine is more likely to cause constipation or reduce bowel motility (leading to constipation), rather than diarrhea.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Urine retention:

  • Atropine can cause urinary retention by relaxing the detrusor muscle of the bladder and contracting the bladder neck, making it more difficult to empty the bladder. This effect is often seen, especially in higher doses.

Option C - Tachycardia:

  • Atropine is known to increase heart rate (tachycardia) by blocking the inhibitory effect of the vagus nerve on the heart, leading to increased heart rate and reduced vagal tone.

Option D - Dry mouth:

  • Dry mouth, also known as xerostomia, is a common side effect of atropine. Atropine inhibits salivary gland secretions, leading to reduced saliva production and the sensation of a dry mouth.

questions.text: Among the following medications, which one is notably associated with an increased risk of renal stone formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Topiramate:

  • Topiramate is a medication primarily used to treat epilepsy and migraine headaches. It is associated with an increased risk of renal stone formation. The precise mechanism is not entirely understood, but it is believed to be related to its effect on the acid-base balance in the body, leading to an increased excretion of substances that can contribute to kidney stone formation. Topiramate-induced kidney stones are typically composed of calcium phosphate.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aspirin:

  • Aspirin is a pain reliever and anti-inflammatory medication, but it is not typically associated with an increased risk of renal stone formation.

Option C - Ibuprofen:

  • Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to relieve pain and inflammation. It is not a known causative factor for kidney stone formation.

Option D - Acetaminophen:

  • Acetaminophen is a pain reliever and fever reducer, and it is not generally associated with the formation of renal stones.
